content:
Neck pain is a common symptom that can occur in a wide variety of conditions, ranging from benign musculoskeletal problems (e.g., neck sprain) to life-threatening neurological or vascular emergencies (e.g., compressive spinal emergencies, myocardial infarction). Initial management involves stabilizing the spine in case of C-spine injury and excluding immediately life-threatening causes of neck pain. Further clinical evaluation includes a focused medical history to evaluate for red flags (e.g., chronic inflammatory conditions, malignancy) and a focused spine examination and neurological examination. Diagnostic testing is guided by clinical evaluation findings and may include imaging and laboratory studies. Management depends on the underlying cause and symptom severity. Emergency surgical management is indicated in some immediately life-threatening causes of neck pain (e.g., vertebral fractures, compressive spinal emergencies, aortic dissection). Symptomatic treatment for non-life-threatening causes of neck pain involves analgesia and physical therapy. Referral for surgery can be considered in patients with chronic neck pain refractory to conservative treatment.

Causes of posterior neck pain [1][2][3]

Mechanical

  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Spondylolisthesis
  • Facet joint syndrome
  • Myofascial pain syndrome
  • Cervical dystonia [4]

Neurological

  • Cervical radiculopathy
  • Cervical myelopathy
  • Occipital neuralgia [5]

Infectious/inflammatory

  • Meningitis
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Spinal epidural abscess
  • Arthritis, e.g., rheumatoid arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR)
  • Fibromyalgia
  • Shingles

Vascular

  • Vertebral artery dissection
  • Vertebral artery thrombosis
  • Spinal epidural hematoma [6]
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage [7]

Traumatic

  • C-spine fracture
  • Cervical vertebral dislocation
  • Atlantoaxial subluxation
  • Neck sprain, whiplash injury

Neoplastic

  • Primary bone tumors
  • Spinal cord tumors
  • Metastatic spinal tumors

Causes of anterior neck pain [1][2][3]

Mechanical

  • Muscle strain
  • Thoracic outlet syndrome

Infectious/inflammatory

  • Deep neck infections
  • Ludwig angina
  • Acute suppurative thyroiditis
  • Pharyngitis
  • Laryngitis
  • Sialadenitis
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Shingles

Neoplastic

  • Thyroid nodule or goiter
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Laryngeal carcinoma
  • Esophageal carcinoma
  • Salivary gland cancers

Others

  • Esophageal disorders (e.g., reflux, esophagitis)
  • Carotid artery dissection

Causes of referred neck pain [1][2][3]

Many thoracic and abdominal conditions can cause pain that radiates to the neck, e.g.:

  • Acute coronary syndrome (ACS)
  • Aortic dissection [8]

Approach [1][2][3]

  • ABCDE survey
  • Traumatic injuries
    • Follow the approach to blunt neck trauma or the approach to penetrating neck trauma.
    • Suspected C-spine injury
      • Immediate spinal precautions, even before airway management
      • Urgent CT C-spine without IV contrast
      • Cervical spine clearance
      • See also “Initial management of C-spine injury.”
  • Assess for red flags in neck pain and identify and manage immediately life-threatening causes of neck pain.
  • Focused clinical evaluation for neck pain
  • Specialist consults as needed (e.g., neurosurgery, neurology, otolaryngology)
  • Obtain etiology-specific diagnostics and initiate treatment.

Maintain a high index of suspicion for traumatic C-spine injuries in older patients and those with certain comorbidities (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, trisomy 21). [1]

Focused history [1][2][9]

Pain characteristics

  • Onset, quality, and duration
  • Location, radiation (e.g., dermatomal distribution)
  • Inciting and relieving factors
  • Pain patterns throughout the day

Associated symptoms

  • Paresthesia, numbness
  • Decreased dexterity, difficulty balancing
  • Clonus, tremor
  • Weakness, muscle atrophy
  • Bladder, bowel, or sexual dysfunction
  • Vertigo
  • Fever, B symptoms
  • Clinical features of ACS

Past medical history

See “Red flags in neck pain” for relevant medical history.

Focused physical examination [1][2][9]

General physical examination

  • Altered mental status
  • Signs of respiratory distress
  • Skin rash
  • Lymphadenopathy

Examination of the spine

  • Tenderness
  • Range of motion
  • Signs of fracture (e.g., palpable step or gap)

Do not examine range of motion before C-spine clearance in symptomatic or obtunded patients. [10]

Neurological examination

  • Meningismus
  • Examination of the motor system
  • Gait examination
  • Examination of the sensory system
  • Cranial nerve examination
  • Provocation maneuvers for cervical radiculopathy

Red flags in neck pain [2][3][9]

Red flag features can suggest a serious underlying cause and should prompt consideration of further diagnostics.

History

  • Risk of decreased structural integrity (e.g., trauma, recent C-spine surgery)
  • Age > 50 years
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., due to long-term steroid use)
  • IV drug use
  • Chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, PMR)
  • Trisomy 21
  • Known malignancy

Features and findings

  • Musculoskeletal: severe neck tenderness, limited neck mobility, torticollis
  • Neurological: signs of stroke, signs of carotid and vertebral artery dissection, signs of compressive myelopathy
  • Infectious/inflammatory: meningismus, fever
  • Cardiovascular: chest pain, diaphoresis, dyspnea, syncope
  • Constitutional: B symptoms

Imaging [1][11]

Indications

  • X-ray C-spine
    • Patients < 16 years of age with history of trauma and who meet criteria for imaging (e.g., NEXUS criteria) [12]
    • Consider for new, increasing, or chronic neck pain and no red flags in neck pain.
  • CT
    • Adults with history of trauma and who meet criteria for imaging (e.g., NEXUS criteria, Canadian C-spine rule): CT C-spine without IV contrast [13]
    • Recent spinal surgery and new or increasing neck pain: CT C-spine without IV contrast
    • Concern for deep neck infection: CT neck with IV contrast [14]
    • Concern for stroke: CT head without IV contrast, additional neuroimaging for acute stroke as indicated [15]
    • Alternative if MRI is contraindicated
  • MRI
    • Concern for spinal infection or known malignancy in patients with new or increasing neck pain: MRI C-spine without and with IV contrast
    • Signs of cervical myelopathy: MRI C-spine without and with IV contrast [16]
    • Chronic neck pain with radiculopathy and no red flags: MRI C-spine without IV contrast
    • Alternative if CT is contraindicated
  • Angiography
    • Concern for carotid or vertebral artery dissection: CTA or MRA head and neck [15][17]
    • Concern for aortic dissection: CTA chest, abdomen, and pelvis [18]

Findings

See “Common immediately life-threatening causes of neck pain”, “Common spinal causes of neck pain”, and “Common nonspinal causes of neck pain.”

Abnormalities are common on C-spine imaging in both symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals; use clinical judgment when interpreting findings. [11]

Electromyography [2]

Consider electromyography in consultation with neurology to assess for neuropathy in patients with numbness, weakness, or pain in the extremities.

Laboratory studies [1][9]

Laboratory studies are not routinely required. Based on the suspected etiology, consider:

  • Sepsis workup
  • Lumbar puncture and CSF analysis
  • Coagulation panel
  • Troponin, D-dimer
  • CMP
Common immediately life-threatening causes of neck pain
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
Unstable vertebral injuries [19]
  • Trauma significant for age or comorbidities
  • Palpable deformity
  • Paravertebral hematoma
  • CT: fracture, displacement
  • See “Diagnostics for C-spine injuries.”
  • Immediate spinal precautions
  • Spine surgery consult
  • See “Initial management of C-spine injuries.”
Compressive spinal emergencies [16][20]
  • Risk factors for compressive spinal emergency
  • Sudden-onset severe radicular pain
  • Symptoms of spinal cord compression
  • MRI: cord compression, mass effect
  • Urgent neurosurgery consult
  • Suspected malignancy: high-dose IV corticosteroids
  • See “Management of compressive spinal emergencies.”
Meningitis [21][22]
  • Fever
  • Meningismus
  • Altered mental state
  • CSF analysis in meningitis: e.g., pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein in bacterial meningitis
  • Blood cultures
  • CT or MRI: normal or mild meningeal enhancement
  • Empiric antibiotics for bacterial meningitis
  • See “Acute management checklist for meningitis.”
Spinal infections [23]
  • Risk factors for spinal infections
  • Fever
  • Slow-onset, localized pain
  • MRI: vertebral and/or disc inflammation, abscess
  • Blood cultures
  • ↑ WBC, ESR, and CRP
  • Empiric antimicrobial therapy for spinal infections
  • Neurosurgery consult
  • See “Treatment of spinal infections.”
ACS [24]
  • Chest pain
  • Diaphoresis
  • Dyspnea
  • ECG changes in STEMI, ECG changes in NSTE-ACS
  • ↑ Troponin
  • See “Diagnosis of ACS.”
  • Reperfusion therapy
  • Antiplatelet therapy
  • See “STEMI management.”
  • See “NSTEMI management.”
Aortic dissection [18]
  • Risk factors for aortic dissection
  • Tearing chest or back pain
  • Asymmetric blood pressure
  • ECG: normal, nonspecific changes, or ECG signs of LVH
  • CTA, MRA, TEE: intimal flap, double lumen
  • See “Diagnosis of aortic dissection.”
  • Urgent cardiothoracic surgery consult
  • Blood pressure management
  • See “Acute management checklist for aortic dissection.”
Carotid and vertebral artery dissection [17]
  • Unilateral neck pain and headache
  • Neck swelling
  • Horner syndrome, cranial nerve lesions
  • Signs of acute ischemic stroke (e.g., vertebrobasilar insufficiency)
  • CTA, MRA: intimal flap, double lumen
  • Vascular surgery consult
  • Antithrombotic therapy
  • See “Treatment of carotid and vertebral artery dissection.”
Deep neck infections [25][26][27]
  • Fever
  • Neck swelling
  • Displacement of uvula and/or pharyngeal wall
  • Trismus
  • Dysphagia, stridor, respiratory distress
  • CT: may show abscess (fluid collection with ring enhancement)
  • Emergency airway management for deep neck infections
  • Empiric antibiotic therapy for deep neck infections
  • ENT and/or maxillofacial surgery consult
  • See “Acute management checklist for deep neck infection.”

Spinal causes of neck pain

Common spinal causes of neck pain
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
Mechanical, nonneuropathic neck pain [1][3]
  • Reduced ROM
  • Paraspinal or midline tenderness
  • No neurological deficits
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Imaging may show degenerative changes.
  • Provide reassurance and patient education.
  • Symptomatic treatment of neck pain
Cervical radiculopathy [11][28]
  • Radicular pain
  • Motor deficits, sensory deficits, and reduced reflexes may be present.
  • See also “Overview of cervical radiculopathies.”
  • Positive provocation maneuvers for cervical radiculopathy
  • MRI: herniation of disc tissue and/or degenerative changes, surrounding edema
  • Symptomatic treatment of neck pain
  • Neurosurgery consult for severe, progressive, or persistent symptoms
  • See “Treatment of degenerative disc disease.”
Myelopathy [16][29][30]
  • LMN signs at the level of the lesion
  • UMN signs below the level of the lesion
  • Sensory and motor deficits (e.g., numbness, clumsiness, gait disturbance)
  • MRI: spinal canal narrowing and spinal cord edema, signs of underlying pathology
  • Symptomatic treatment, immobilization
  • Neurosurgery consult
  • See “Treatment of cervical myelopathy.”
Spinal tumors and metastases [9][31][32]
  • History of cancer or risk factors
  • Chronic, dull pain that is worse at night and/or at rest
  • B symptoms
  • ↑ ESR, ALP, or calcium
  • MRI: tumor size, affected structures
  • See “Diagnostics for malignant bone tumors.”
  • Oncology and spine surgery consult
  • Symptomatic management (e.g., corticosteroids)
  • See “Malignant bone tumors.”
Spinal stenosis [3]
  • Pain radiating to extremities, paresthesias
  • Pain worsens with neck extension. [2]
  • Gait disturbance
  • MRI: narrowing of the spinal canal, degenerative changes
  • Symptomatic treatment of neck pain
  • Neurosurgery consult
  • See “Treatment of spinal stenosis.”
Chronic inflammatory conditions [33][34][35]
  • Morning stiffness
  • Joint swelling and/or tenderness
  • Constitutional symptoms
  • Extraarticular manifestations
  • ↑ ESR and/or CRP
  • Additional diagnostics (e.g., HLA-B27) in consultation with rheumatology
  • X-ray, MRI: degenerative changes, ankylosis
  • Symptomatic treatment of neck pain
  • Antiinflammatory treatment (e.g., NSAIDs)
  • Refer to rheumatology.

Nonspinal causes of neck pain

Common nonspinal causes of neck pain
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
GERD, esophagitis [36]
  • Heartburn
  • Regurgitation
  • Dysphagia
  • EGD : erythema, erosions
  • See “Diagnostics of GERD” and “Approach to esophagitis.”
  • PPI therapy
  • Lifestyle changes
  • See “Management of GERD” and “Approach to esophagitis.”
Malignancy [37][38]
  • History of cancer or risk factors
  • Neck mass
  • Dysphagia, foreign body sensation
  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Hoarseness
  • Diagnostics and findings depend on the location and suspected malignancy, e.g.:
    • “Diagnostics for thyroid cancer”
    • “Diagnostics for esophageal cancer”
    • “Diagnostics for laryngeal cancer”
  • Oncology consult
  • See, e.g.:
    • “Treatment of thyroid cancer”
    • “Treatment of esophageal cancer”
    • “Treatment of laryngeal cancer”
Lymphadenopathy [39][40]
  • Painless or tender swollen lymph nodes
  • Possible signs of infection or malignancy
  • Diagnostics depend on the suspected underlying cause; see “Diagnostics for lymphadenopathy.”
  • Ultrasound: A round shape and loss of echogenic hilum suggest malignancy.
  • Treatment of underlying cause
  • See “Management of lymphadenopathy.”
Uncomplicated laryngitis/pharyngitis [41][42]
  • Sore throat
  • Hoarseness
  • Fever
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Further testing based on clinical suspicion (e.g., rapid strep test)
  • Vocal rest, supportive care for laryngitis
  • Hydration, analgesia
  • See “Management of acute laryngitis” and “Acute management checklist for acute pharyngitis.”
Thoracic outlet syndrome [43][44]
  • Pain and/or paresthesia in neck, shoulder, and arm
  • Exacerbated by overhead movements
  • Positive provocation tests for thoracic outlet syndrome
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Imaging depends on affected structures and may show structural abnormalities (e.g., cervical rib on chest x-ray).
  • Symptomatic or surgical management depending on severity
  • See “Treatment of thoracic outlet syndrome.”
Shingles [45]
  • Dermatomal, erythematous rash with macules and papules which evolve into vesicles
  • Fever
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • VZV DNA PCR
  • Antiviral therapy for shingles

Symptomatic treatment of neck pain [1][2][9]

Studies on the treatment of neck pain are lacking; many recommendations are derived from studies on back pain. If pain persists despite symptomatic treatment, consider referral for surgical evaluation.

  • Pharmacological treatment
    • Oral analgesics
      • Mild to moderate pain: NSAIDs
      • Moderate to severe pain: opioids, e.g., tramadol (second-line; for acute neck pain only)
    • Topical analgesics: NSAIDs, lidocaine patches
    • Injection of local anesthetics, corticosteroids, and botulinum toxin may be beneficial for certain causes.
    • Additional options with limited evidence include muscle relaxants and oral corticosteroids for radiculopathy.
  • Nonpharmacological treatments
    • Physical therapy, strengthening exercises
    • Consider referral for psychotherapy, particularly for patients with risk factors for persistent neck pain. [2][46]
    • Additional options with limited evidence include spinal manipulation, massage therapy, and acupuncture.
  • ABCDE approach
  • Spinal precautions for C-spine injury
  • Clinical evaluation for neck pain, focusing on red flags in neck pain
  • Manage immediately life-threatening causes of neck pain.
  • Diagnostics for neck pain guided by clinical suspicion
  • Specialist consults as needed (e.g., neurosurgery, neurology)
  • Treatment of underlying cause; symptomatic treatment of neck pain if no underlying cause found
